24.text:
I actually went to Africa and worked in an
orphanage where most of the children had HIV and TB.

29.text:
I came home and I just felt like I
had to do something.

32.text:
I felt really passionate
that this was something I wanted to do.

35.text:
I went online and looked at 
rankings of various Universities

39.text:
and came across the University of York, 
and that's how I ended up here.

44.text:
The masters in public Health, coming from
a medical perspective, it takes you from one

50.text:
level to another and widens your horizons.
You can see beyond curative and diagnostic medicine.

59.text:
You are now looking at the preventative part of it 
and the causes of these conditions that you are trying to cure.

65.text:
What blew me away, was when I came here and looked at the rest
of the faculty and I went through their background...

71.text: It was perhaps the best decision I've made.

77.text: My experience of the course so far has been stellar.

79.text:
I have met some many new people and
we have someone from almost every continent.

86.text:
With that comes different perspectives 
and angles about major public health issues

90.text: and health services around the world.

93.text:
It is fascinating to interact with students
from other places.

96.text:
To ask them how is the health system 
set up in their country?

102.text:
What are the major diseases that we're not faced
with on a daily basis?

106.text:
I've been able to relate my profession to the healthcare 
system and how it needs to be promoted in the future.

113.text:
So I've knitted together my old career and 
hopefully my new career, which has been fantastic.

118.text:
York is a small, historic town, it's safe
but with loads of entertainment on your downtime.

128.text:
Having a world class University nested in the
centre of that is a beautiful environment to study in.
